study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of vitamin D supplementation on hormonal parameters, lipid profiles, serum irisin, and obesity indices in women with subclinical hypothyroidism.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation significantly decreased TSH, total cholesterol, and fat mass percentage while increasing serum vitamin D, irisin levels, and fat-free mass percentage. No significant changes were observed in other thyroid hormones, lipid profiles, or anthropometric indices.
population_specificity: 44 women with subclinical hypothyroidism (22 in the vitamin D group, 22 in the placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether vitamin D supplementation could reduce statin-associated muscle symptoms (SAMS) in patients on statin therapy.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in objective muscle damage measures or physical performance with vitamin D supplementation. Subjective measures of muscle symptoms and quality of life worsened after statin reintroduction, regardless of supplementation.
population_specificity: Men and women (n=38, mean age 50.5 ± 7.7 years) in primary cardiovascular prevention, with or without self-reported SAMS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between vitamin D supplementation or serum vitamin D levels and neuropsychiatric manifestations in patients with SLE or NPSLE, as well as in animal models.
results_summary: The study suggests that vitamin D deficiency is associated with cognition deficits and cerebral hypoperfusion in NPSLE patients. It reviews evidence linking vitamin D levels to neuropsychiatric symptoms in SLE/NPSLE, though specific outcomes of supplementation are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or neuropsychiatric lupus (NPSLE), and animal models of NPSLE.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effects of vitamin D deficiency on physical function and quality of life after hip fractures through a meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in walking ability between vitamin D-deficient and normal-level patients but suggested that screening and optimizing vitamin D levels could aid rehabilitation and recovery. The results were limited by small sample size and heterogeneous assessments.
population_specificity: Patients with hip fractures

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of Vitamin D supplementation on systolic (SBP) and diastolic (DBP) blood pressure levels in individuals with hypertension and hypovitaminosis D.
results_summary: Vitamin D significantly decreased SBP levels but did not affect DBP levels. Subgroup analyses showed significant SBP reductions in individuals over 60, with doses >400,000 IU, durations >8 weeks, weekly supplementation, and in studies conducted in Asia.
population_specificity: Individuals with hypertension and hypovitaminosis D.
effective_dosage: Greater than 400,000 IU, weekly frequency in some subgroups.
study_duration: Greater than 8 weeks in effective subgroups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical significance of vitamin D in adult orthopaedics and traumatology, focusing on its supplementation and association with postoperative outcomes.
results_summary: The study highlights the association between low vitamin D status and worse postoperative outcomes, emphasizing the practical aspects of vitamin D supplementation with pathophysiological and epidemiological rationale.
population_specificity: Adult patients in orthopaedics and traumatology.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine differences in serum 25(OH)D levels between NMOSD patients and healthy controls and assess the potential link between vitamin D deficiency and NMOSD.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significantly lower serum 25(OH)D levels in NMOSD patients compared to healthy controls, with a 23.36 times higher risk of deficiency in NMOSD patients. However, no causal relationship between vitamin D levels and NMOSD onset was established.
population_specificity: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) patients and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of oral vitamin D supplementation on TLR-2 and TLR-4 levels in tuberculosis spondylitis patients.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation at 10,000 IU and 5,000 IU doses significantly increased vitamin D, TLR-2, and TLR-4 levels by weeks 4 and 8, while the control group showed no significant increase. The study concluded that vitamin D supplementation can enhance TLR-2 and TLR-4 levels, with 10,000 IU/day for 8 weeks raising vitamin D levels sufficiently for optimal immunomodulatory effects.
population_specificity: Tuberculosis spondylitis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the comparative efficacy of different vitamin D supplementation dosages on cardiometabolic and bone-metabolic indicators, as well as insulin resistance, in children and adolescents with overweight/obesity.
results_summary: The study found that extremely high-dose vitamin D supplementation (EHDS) significantly increased 25-(OH)-D levels, reduced HOMA-IR (insulin resistance), and decreased CRP (inflammatory marker) compared to lower doses and placebo. EHDS ranked best for these outcomes with high probability (76.6%-86.1%).
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with overweight/obesity.
effective_dosage: Low (<1000 IU/day), medium (1000-2000 IU/day), high (2000-4000 IU/day), and extremely high (>4000 IU/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation affects coronary heart disease, stroke, and all-cause mortality, particularly in individuals with low vitamin D status.
results_summary: Observational analyses suggested inverse associations between low 25(OH)D concentrations and cardiovascular/mortality outcomes, but Mendelian randomization analyses found no causal relationship at any 25(OH)D level. The study concluded that vitamin D supplementation is unlikely to significantly reduce mortality or cardiovascular morbidity.
population_specificity: 500,962 individuals in observational studies and 386,406 middle-aged individuals of European ancestry in Mendelian randomization analyses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence of insufficient serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels in neurological patients and compare it to the general Croatian population, while also examining differences based on gender, season, region, supplementation, and autoimmune disease diagnosis.
results_summary: The study found that 74.66% of neurological patients had insufficient 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels, slightly lower than the general population. No significant differences were found by gender, season, or region, but significant differences were observed based on vitamin D3 supplementation and autoimmune disease diagnosis.
population_specificity: 371 neurological patients in Croatia over a one-year period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update the initial report on the link between vitamin D deficiency and COVID-19 mortality using multi-country data from 19 European countries.
results_summary: The study found that countries with average 25(OH) vitamin D levels >50 nmol/L had lower COVID-19 mortality rates (RR = 0.794) and a statistically significant negative correlation between vitamin D levels and mortality.
population_specificity: 19 European countries (general population data).
study_duration: Data collected from 1 March 2020 to 14 June 2023.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels and vitamin D deficiency in patients with non-scarring alopecia compared to healthy controls.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that non-scarring alopecia patients had significantly lower serum 25(OH)D levels and a higher incidence of vitamin D deficiency compared to healthy controls, suggesting a potential role for vitamin D supplementation in treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with non-scarring alopecia (including androgenetic alopecia, female pattern hair loss, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium) and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of vitamin D supplementation on inflammation and dyslipidemia in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D supplementation significantly reduced tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) levels, suggesting potential benefits in ameliorating inflammation and dyslipidemia in T2D patients.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of regulated vitamin D increase on vascular markers (FMD, PWV, AIx) in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: Vitamin D and VDRA supplementation showed a non-significant improvement in FMD but no significant effect on arterial stiffness (PWV and AIx), suggesting potential vascular function benefits without reducing cardiovascular disease incidence.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness and safety of vitamin D supplementation for treating psoriasis based on published randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of vitamin D supplementation on psoriasis severity or quality of life indices, though subgroup analyses suggested potential effectiveness with vitamin D2 or in Asian populations. No serious adverse effects were reported, with only minor nausea in a few individuals.
population_specificity: 333 patients with psoriasis from 4 studies.
study_duration: Follow-up periods included 3 months, 6 months, and end of follow-up (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an individualized loading dose of vitamin D supplementation is more effective than a standardized dose in helping athletes achieve a target blood concentration of 40 ng/mL.
results_summary: The individualized group (4000 IU/day loading dose followed by 1000 IU/day maintenance) achieved significantly higher 25(OH)D levels (41.1 ng/mL) compared to the standardized group (2000 IU/day, 32.5 ng/mL) at the target date. The study suggests that tailored dosing may be more effective for athletes to reach optimal vitamin D levels.
population_specificity: 90 athletes with insufficient vitamin D levels (25(OH)D < 30 ng/mL) during winter in Germany.
effective_dosage: 2000 IU/day (standardized) vs. 4000 IU/day loading dose followed by 1000 IU/day maintenance (individualized).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare healthcare costs and utilization between a group supplemented with vitamin D3 (5000 IU) and a non-supplemented control group.
results_summary: Vitamin D3 supplementation reduced healthcare utilization in four major categories, including hospitalizations, though cost differences were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate whether vitamin D insufficiency is a risk factor for chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) in patients receiving paclitaxel.
results_summary: The study found that patients with vitamin D insufficiency had a higher incidence of severe CIPN (20.7% vs. 14.2%), and mouse experiments confirmed that vitamin D deficiency sensitized mice to paclitaxel-induced mechanical hypersensitivity. The association remained significant after adjusting for age and paclitaxel schedule but not race.
population_specificity: Female patients with early-stage breast cancer receiving paclitaxel-containing chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (measured pretreatment 25-hydroxy-vitamin D levels, with insufficiency defined as ≤20 ng/mL).
study_duration: Not specified (study analyzed pretreatment levels and outcomes during chemotherapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of vitamin D supplementation in maintaining or restoring vitamin D levels in individuals with Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
results_summary: The study found that current dosing regimens prevent severe deficiency but are ineffective at maintaining sufficient vitamin D levels in the Duchenne population, with at least 20% remaining deficient despite high daily supplementation (>1000 IU). No significant association between dose and serum vitamin D levels was observed.
population_specificity: Individuals with Duchenne muscular dystrophy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between vitamin D and muscle regeneration, function, and recovery in both animal models and humans.
results_summary: The study found strong associations between vitamin D and skeletal muscle function, regeneration, and recovery, with benefits observed in myoblast growth, grip strength, and endurance. However, no benefits were noted in rotator cuff injury recovery, suggesting context-dependent efficacy.
population_specificity: Mice, humans (particularly the elderly), and post-surgery or post-exercise recovery patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the significance of high sCD40L levels in clinical oncology and evaluate the impact of vitamin D3 supplementation on relapse-free survival in patients with digestive tract cancer.
results_summary: The study found that higher serum sCD40L levels were associated with significantly lower 5-year relapse-free survival rates in colorectal cancer patients. Vitamin D3 supplementation showed a protective effect, with the lowest sCD40L tertile having a significantly lower risk of relapse or death compared to the highest tertile.
population_specificity: Patients with digestive tract cancer, specifically colorectal cancer (CRC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of vitamin D2 and vitamin D3 on raising serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] levels and to assess the impact of response modifiers on heterogeneity.
results_summary: Vitamin D3 was found to be superior to vitamin D2 in raising total 25(OH)D concentrations, but both forms had similar positive effects on their corresponding hydroxylated forms. Baseline 25(OH)D and BMI were identified as factors influencing the comparison.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.
effective_dosage: Daily or once/twice weekly dosing (specific amounts not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of different doses of maternal vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy on child health outcomes, including rickets, respiratory diseases, and diarrhea/vomiting, up to two years of age.
results_summary: Higher doses of vitamin D (2000 and 4000 IU/day) during pregnancy were associated with lower incidences of rickets, respiratory diseases (e.g., pneumonia), and diarrhea/vomiting in children compared to the 600 IU/day group. The study found a dose-response relationship, with the 4000 IU/day group showing the most significant reductions in these health risks.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in Mongolia and their children followed up to two years of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a loading dose of vitamin D3 (100,000 IU) pre-aHSCT could achieve and maintain sufficient post-transplant vitamin D levels (≥75 nmol/L) and improve bone health.
results_summary: The high vitamin D group showed significantly higher 25(OH)D levels at day 30 post-transplant compared to the control group, with a trend toward higher sufficiency rates. However, the primary outcome of sustained superiority at day 100 was not met. Baseline vitamin D insufficiency was an independent risk factor for post-transplant insufficiency.
population_specificity: Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (aHSCT) patients at high risk of vitamin D deficiency.
effective_dosage: High vitamin D group: single loading dose (100,000 IU) plus 2,000 IU daily; control group: 2,000 IU daily.
study_duration: Follow-up at baseline, day 30, and day 100 post-aHSCT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of vitamin D supplementation on 25(OH)D levels, insulin resistance, fasting blood glucose, and fasting insulin levels in patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation significantly increased 25(OH)D levels but had no significant effect on insulin resistance, fasting blood glucose, or fasting insulin levels. The meta-analysis included eight randomized controlled trials with mixed results on metabolic outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation reduces exacerbations and improves pulmonary function in COPD patients with vitamin D deficiency.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation did not significantly reduce exacerbations or improve pulmonary function (FEV1 or FEV1/FVC ratio) but did increase serum 25(OH)D levels.
population_specificity: 522 COPD patients with vitamin D deficiency (25(OH)D < 50 nmol/L), including 61 with severe deficiency (25(OH)D < 25 nmol/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of vitamin D supplementation on depression in adults, particularly focusing on subgroups with different baseline 25(OH)D levels.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation significantly reduced depressive symptom scores overall, with a stronger effect observed in individuals with serum 25(OH)D levels higher than 50 nmol/L. No significant effect was found in those with levels below 50 nmol/L.
population_specificity: Adults with primary depression, stratified by baseline 25(OH)D levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between maternal Vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy and neurodevelopmental outcomes in children aged 3-5 years.
results_summary: Higher 25(OH)D concentrations at testing were associated with better neurodevelopmental performance, and higher maternal Vitamin D doses during pregnancy showed a positive association with neurodevelopmental outcomes. The VDBP genotype also influenced neurodevelopment.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their children aged 3-5 years.
effective_dosage: 400 IU, 2000 IU, or 4000 IU Vitamin D.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of low vitamin D levels in contributing to susceptibility to multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found that low vitamin D levels significantly contribute to MS susceptibility, suggesting a link between vitamin D deficiency and the development of MS. The abstract does not provide detailed results on the extent of this contribution or specific outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation significantly impacts the risk of cardiovascular and cerebrovascular events.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between vitamin D supplementation and placebo in reducing the risk of cardiovascular mortality, stroke, myocardial infarction, cerebrovascular mortality, arrhythmias, or hemorrhagic/ischemic stroke. No significant heterogeneity was observed between studies.
population_specificity: 493,389 participants across 36 trials (general population, not specifically high-risk or vitamin D-deficient).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of vitamin D supplementation in the prevention and treatment of SARS-CoV-2 infection through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation did not show conclusive preventive effects against SARS-CoV-2 infection but significantly reduced ICU admission and mechanical ventilation rates in treatment. It also reduced mortality in vitamin D-deficient patients.
population_specificity: 8,128 participants across 25 trials, including both preventive and treatment contexts for SARS-CoV-2 infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-dose vitamin D injections could improve lower back pain, spinal function, and quality of life in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis and vitamin D deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D supplementation significantly improved lower back pain, spinal function, and quality of life in patients with spinal stenosis compared to the non-supplementation group, with statistically significant improvements observed at multiple follow-up intervals.
population_specificity: Patients with spinal stenosis and serum 25-hydroxy vitamin D levels < 10 ng/mL (26 in the supplementation group, 25 in the non-supplementation group).
effective_dosage: High-dose vitamin D injections (specific dosage not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence on parental adherence to vitamin D supplementation guidelines in children under five years of age.
results_summary: The study found that adherence to vitamin D supplementation guidelines in children under five was generally poor, ranging from 14.29% to 95.6%, with most studies reporting low or moderate adherence. The evidence was limited by methodological heterogeneity and a focus on infants.
population_specificity: Children under five years of age, primarily infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether clinical trials on vitamin D were adequately designed to assess its antifracture efficacy by comparing them against expert opinions and protocols of proven antifracture medications.
results_summary: The study found that most trials did not measure serum vitamin D levels adequately and failed to conclusively assess vitamin D's antifracture efficacy, particularly in patients with low prestudy vitamin D levels. The trials also lacked sufficient data on dosage and preparation effectiveness in specific populations.
population_specificity: Primarily elderly adults, with two exceptions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of vitamin D supplementation as a treatment for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D may reduce clinical relapses in IBD compared to placebo, but evidence for clinical response, quality of life, and withdrawals was inconclusive due to very low certainty. High-dose versus low-dose comparisons showed no clear differences in relapse rates for Crohn’s disease.
population_specificity: People of all ages with active or inactive IBD, including Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis.
effective_dosage: Doses ranged from supplemental (<400 IU/day), low-treatment (400-1000 IU/day), to high-treatment (>1000 IU/day).
study_duration: Study durations varied from 4 to 52 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation could improve periodontal conditions in a patient with early-onset periodontitis and vitamin D deficiency.
results_summary: Following 1-year therapy with vitamin D supplementation and periodontal treatment, the patient's periodontal conditions improved, and vitamin D levels normalized. The case suggests a potential link between vitamin D deficiency and early-onset periodontitis.
population_specificity: A 12-year-old girl with early-onset periodontitis and vitamin D deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential impact of prenatal Vitamin D levels on dental health outcomes in children, including enamel defects and tooth erosion.
results_summary: The study found diverse associations between prenatal Vitamin D levels and dental outcomes, with maternal Vitamin D insufficiency linked to higher risks of enamel defects, while high levels showed protective effects against certain dental conditions. However, results varied across studies, and the assessment of Vitamin D deficiency was inconsistent.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their children (ages 3.6 to 6.6 years at examination).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of oral vitamin D supplementation on serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) levels in healthy adults in Europe to inform health authority recommendations.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation significantly increased serum 25(OH)D levels by 36.28 nmol/L compared to placebo, with a relative increment of 1.77 nmol/L per 2.5 μg daily. The effect varied by dosage and baseline levels, and an estimated daily dose of 25 μg (1000 IU) would raise levels to ≥50 nmol/L in 95% of the population.
population_specificity: Healthy adults in Europe

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between serum vitamin D levels and paediatric migraine by reviewing existing literature.
results_summary: The systematic review found a notable association between vitamin D and migraine presentation in children, affecting the frequency and duration of episodes, suggesting that supplementation could improve quality of life.
population_specificity: Paediatric patients suffering from migraine headaches.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the prevalence and associated factors of vitamin D deficiency (VDD) after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB).
results_summary: The study found a high prevalence (42%) of VDD after RYGB, with higher rates linked to longer follow-up time, inadequate supplementation, and certain populations (e.g., Asia, black populations). Factors like presurgical VDD prevalence and patient noncompliance also contributed to higher VDD rates.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB).
study_duration: Follow-up durations varied: ≤1 year, >1 to ≤5 years, and >5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether vitamin D supplementation enhances the efficacy and safety of mometasone nasal spray in treating allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation significantly improved nasal symptoms, immune markers, and quality of life in patients with allergic rhinitis, showing greater efficacy than mometasone alone. Adverse reactions were recorded but not detailed, suggesting general safety.
population_specificity: 140 patients with moderate to severe allergic rhinitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing evidence on Vitamin D's impact on vaginal, sexual, and urological health in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that Vitamin D supplementation improved vulvovaginal symptoms, including vaginal pH, dryness, sexual functioning, and reduced urinary tract infections, with Vitamin D receptors (VDRs) playing a key role in these effects. However, further investigation is needed to fully characterize these effects.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the efficacy of nutritional supplementation, including Vitamin D, on muscle and mitochondrial health in sarcopenic or malnourished older adults.
results_summary: BCAA with Vitamin D significantly improved appendicular muscle mass, hand grip strength, gait speed, and physical performance in older adults with sarcopenia. Vitamin D in combination with BCAA also enhanced mitochondrial function.
population_specificity: Older adults with sarcopenia and/or malnutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of vitamin D supplementation on lipid profile components (LDL cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, total cholesterol, and triglycerides) through an umbrella meta-analysis of existing meta-analyses.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation significantly decreased triglyceride and total cholesterol levels and increased HDL cholesterol levels, suggesting it could be a beneficial adjuvant therapy for managing lipid profiles, particularly in individuals with vitamin D deficiency.
population_specificity: Individuals with noncommunicable chronic diseases, particularly those with vitamin D deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation improves bone mineral density in children and adolescents, particularly based on baseline vitamin D status.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation had a small overall effect on total hip areal BMD but no clinically important benefits for bone density in healthy children and adolescents, regardless of baseline vitamin D status. The findings are mostly generalizable to White postpubertal girls and do not apply to those with symptomatic vitamin D deficiency.
population_specificity: Healthy children and adolescents aged 1-19 years, predominantly White postpubertal girls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of vitamin D deficiency among Japanese multiple myeloma (MM) patients and its correlation with clinical outcomes, including survival and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found that 32% of MM patients were vitamin D deficient, and deficiency was associated with worse overall survival and lower quality of life scores. Vitamin D supplementation increased P1NP levels in patients achieving complete remission but did not affect TRACP-5b.
population_specificity: Japanese multiple myeloma patients (n=68) at a single institution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between vitamin D levels and sarcopenia/dynapenia in patients with stage 3 or 4 CKD.
results_summary: No relationship was found between sarcopenia alone and vitamin D levels, but severe sarcopenia and dynapenia were directly related to hypovitaminosis D. Higher vitamin D levels (above 40 ng/ml) correlated with better muscle performance, though supplementation showed no effect on muscle performance.
population_specificity: 101 patients over 18 years old with stage 3 or 4 CKD in Manizales, Colombia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare early molecular response rates at 3 months of imatinib therapy with and without vitamin D supplementation in chronic myeloid leukemia patients.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D supplementation was associated with improved early molecular response rates in patients receiving imatinib therapy, though baseline vitamin D deficiency was common.
population_specificity: Treatment-naive patients with chronic phase chronic myeloid leukemia aged >12 years, excluding those with progressive disease, pregnancy, or hypercalcemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the difference in serum vitamin D levels between migraineurs and nonmigraineurs, the association between hypovitaminosis D and migraine, and the effects of vitamin D supplementation on migraine symptoms compared to placebo.
results_summary: Migraineurs had significantly lower serum vitamin D levels than nonmigraineurs, and hypovitaminosis D was associated with migraine. Vitamin D supplementation reduced migraine frequency but did not affect duration or severity.
population_specificity: Migraineurs and nonmigraineurs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether systematic vitamin D repletion could improve clinical outcomes and reduce toxicity in patients with advanced cancer receiving immune-checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs).
results_summary: The study found that systematic vitamin D supplementation led to adequate repletion in most patients and was associated with longer overall survival, time to treatment failure, and higher disease control rate compared to a control group without systematic repletion. Additionally, it suggested a decreased risk of thyroid immune-related adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced cancer receiving immune-checkpoint inhibitors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to resolve conflicting meta-analysis results regarding the effect of vitamin D on blood pressure by conducting an umbrella meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D significantly reduced systolic blood pressure based on weighted mean difference analysis, suggesting it could be an efficient adjuvant for improving blood pressure.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of clinical trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the pharmacokinetics of oral Vitamin D in children with asthma and identify the optimal dosing regimen to achieve therapeutic 25(OH)D concentrations.
results_summary: The study found that a daily dose of 8000 IU with a loading dose of 50,000 IU effectively raised 25(OH)D concentrations above 40 ng/mL in most participants without exceeding 100 ng/mL. Obesity significantly impacted vitamin D clearance and half-life, with higher BMI z-scores associated with faster clearance.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-17 years with asthma who were overweight or obese and had baseline serum 25(OH)D concentrations between 10 and <30 ng/mL.
effective_dosage: 8000 IU daily with a 50,000 IU loading dose (Part 1), compared to a standard dose of 600 IU daily (Part 2).
study_duration: 16 weeks for each part (Part 1 and Part 2), with additional pharmacokinetic sampling over 28 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of vitamin D in preventing and mitigating chronic diseases and infections, and its broader physiological benefits.
results_summary: The study found that maintaining vitamin D sufficiency (serum 25(OH)D above 40 ng/mL) improves immune function, reduces chronic disease burden, infections, hospitalizations, and all-cause mortality. It also controls inflammation, oxidative stress, and generates antimicrobial peptides.
population_specificity: Vulnerable communities, including ethnic minorities in temperate countries, older people, those with co-morbidities, night workers, and institutionalized persons.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether cholecalciferol (D3) supplementation could prevent incident vertebral fractures (i-VFs) in acromegaly patients.
results_summary: D3 supplementation was associated with a lower prevalence of i-VFs (14.3% in treated vs. 85.7% in untreated patients). Higher serum V25OH-D levels were linked to reduced fracture risk, and logistic regression confirmed D3's protective role (OR: 0.16).
population_specificity: 61 acromegaly patients (treated and untreated with D3).

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of vitamin D supplementation on pregnancy and ovulation rates in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation significantly increased pregnancy, ovulation, and matured oocytes rates while reducing early miscarriage rates, androgen levels, luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, and premature delivery rates. No significant improvements were observed in fertilization rate, cleavage rate, or other secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation reduces the risk of relapse or death in a subgroup of patients with digestive tract cancer who were p53 immunoreactive.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D supplementation significantly improved 5-year relapse-free survival in p53-immunoreactive patients (80.9% vs. 30.6% in the placebo group), but had no effect in non-p53-immunoreactive patients.
population_specificity: Patients with digestive tract cancers (esophageal, gastric, small bowel, colorectal) who were p53 immunoreactive.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of vitamin D supplementation in COVID-19 patients, focusing on length of hospital stay, ICU admission rates, and mortality.
results_summary: High-dose vitamin D supplementation showed potential benefits in reducing hospital stay and ICU admission rates, but its effect on mortality was not statistically significant. The study noted high heterogeneity and limitations among the included trials.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients
effective_dosage: High-dose (specific amount not detailed in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between vitamin D levels and psoriasis, and assess the efficacy of oral vitamin D supplementation in improving psoriasis severity.
results_summary: Psoriasis patients had significantly lower serum 25(OH)D levels compared to controls. The study also evaluated the efficacy of oral vitamin D supplementation in improving Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) scores, though specific results on efficacy were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 1876 psoriasis patients and 7532 controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the connection between vitamin D levels and the severity of acute respiratory tract infections (ARTIs), including COVID-19, in pediatric populations, and to assess whether vitamin D supplementation could influence disease outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D may lower the risk of ARTIs, including COVID-19, through immunomodulatory and antiviral effects, but conclusive evidence on its impact on disease severity and recovery in children remains limited.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with acute respiratory tract infections, including COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-term Vitamin D supplementation could improve antioxidant capacity in inactive men following exhaustive aerobic exercise.
results_summary: The study found that six weeks of Vitamin D supplementation significantly increased antioxidant enzyme activity (superoxide dismutase, glutathione peroxidase, catalase, peroxidase) and Vitamin D levels compared to placebo, suggesting it may help prevent oxidative damage from exhaustive exercise.
population_specificity: 24 non-athlete, inactive men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical evidence of vitamin D supplementation, alone or combined with other strategies, in preventing sarcopenia in non-sarcopenic individuals and improving muscle strength, mass, and function in sarcopenic individuals without vitamin D deficiency.
results_summary: Vitamin D alone showed a subtle beneficial effect on knee extensor strength in non-sarcopenic individuals at doses of 880-1600 IU/day but did not improve handgrip strength or muscle mass. In sarcopenic individuals, vitamin D co-supplementation with protein increased handgrip strength by 9.8-40.5%, but no strong evidence linked dosage to muscle strength or mass changes.
population_specificity: Non-sarcopenic individuals and sarcopenic individuals without vitamin D deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Vitamin D supplements on clinically relevant outcomes, particularly in people with chronic kidney disease, and to reconcile discrepancies between observational data and clinical trial results.
results_summary: Large clinical trials contradicted observational data, showing no significant benefits of Vitamin D supplements on fracture, cardiovascular, cancer, or mortality outcomes. The study discusses potential reasons for these discrepancies.
population_specificity: General population and people with chronic kidney disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of Vitamin D deficiency in Indian rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients and evaluate its association with disease activity.
results_summary: The study found that 80% of RA patients had low Vitamin D levels, with 56% deficient and 20% insufficient. A negative correlation was observed between serum Vitamin D levels and RA disease activity.
population_specificity: Indian patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of vitamin D supplementation on serum vitamin D levels, metabolic factors related to insulin resistance, and symptom severity in patients with schizophrenia.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation significantly reduced waist circumference, PANSS-TS scores, and GSK-3β levels in patients with schizophrenia, suggesting potential benefits for symptom severity and insulin resistance biomarkers.
population_specificity: 48 chronic male patients with schizophrenia and vitamin D deficiency (≤20 ng/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the factors affecting body composition in IBD patients, including the role of vitamin D deficiency, and to summarize interventions like vitamin D supplementation for improving body composition.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D deficiency is a contributing factor to altered body composition in IBD patients, and supplementation of vitamin D is important for improving body composition distribution.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including Crohn's disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between serum/supplemental Vitamin D levels and insulin resistance, as well as its potential role in type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that Vitamin D supplementation significantly improved serum insulin, glucose, and HOMA-IR levels in diabetics, with a significant inverse correlation between Vitamin D levels and insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Diabetic individuals (1243 in RCTs, 11,063 in observational studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the potential role of vitamin D in modulating immune pathways and improving thyroid function in Hashimoto's thyroiditis (HT) patients.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation showed promise in reducing antithyroid antibody levels, improving thyroid function, and modulating immune markers such as cytokines and T-cell subsets, suggesting potential benefits for HT management.
population_specificity: Children, adolescents, and obese individuals with higher prevalence of thyroid autoimmunity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential effects of high-dose vitamin D supplementation in combination with chemotherapy on outcomes in patients with advanced or metastatic colorectal cancer and its impact on inflammatory markers and antioxidant capacity in women with breast cancer.
results_summary: High-dose vitamin D supplementation plus chemotherapy in colorectal cancer patients showed a median progression-free survival of 13.0 months. In breast cancer patients, vitamin D supplementation significantly increased serum vitamin D levels.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced or metastatic colorectal cancer and women with breast cancer.
effective_dosage: High-dose (specific amount not provided in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore potential associations between vitamin D deficiency and Graves' disease, and whether vitamin D supplementation might be beneficial in hyperthyroidism therapy.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that vitamin D deficiency may coexist with Graves' disease and could be involved in bone remodeling, but it does not provide conclusive evidence on whether vitamin D supplementation is effective in treating hyperthyroidism or improving bone mineral density.
population_specificity: Patients with Graves' disease and potential vitamin D deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between vitamin D status and all-cause mortality and cardiovascular disease in people with type 2 diabetes or prediabetes.
results_summary: Vitamin D deficiency and insufficiency were associated with higher risks of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality, but supplementation did not reduce these risks. The lowest risk was observed at serum 25(OH)D concentrations of ~60 nmol/L.
population_specificity: People with type 2 diabetes or prediabetes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of intramuscular high-dose vitamin D supplementation in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and distal symmetric polyneuropathy combined with vitamin D insufficiency.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study is described as a planned randomized controlled trial. Previous interventional studies mentioned found low-dose vitamin D supplementation did not significantly improve neuropathy.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and distal symmetric polyneuropathy combined with vitamin D insufficiency.
effective_dosage: High-dose vitamin D (specific amount not stated), administered once a month via intramuscular injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining exercise with vitamin D supplementation could improve insulin resistance and glycemic control in individuals with type 2 diabetes, and whether baseline lipidome profiles could predict intervention responsiveness.
results_summary: The interventions did not improve the HOMA-IR index, but fasting glucose was reduced in the combined exercise and vitamin D group. Machine learning was used to predict glycemic control responsiveness, though specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Participants with type 2 diabetes (n=61).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Vitamin D supplementation as part of nutritional support to address health-related problems like sarcopenia, frailty, and fractures in super-aging societies.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that Vitamin D supplementation, alongside adequate energy and protein intake, could be crucial in managing chronic diseases and preventing fractures in elderly populations, though specific efficacy data is not detailed.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals in super-aging societies, particularly those with comorbidities like diabetes, chronic kidney disease, and sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of vitamin D supplementation on fatigue in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a significant reduction in fatigue with vitamin D supplementation compared to a control group, with a pooled effect size of -0.18 (95% CI: -0.36 to -0.01).
population_specificity: 345 individuals (271 females; age range: 25.4-41.1 years) with multiple sclerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing guidelines on vitamin D supplementation for patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) on dialysis.
results_summary: The study found promising potential effectiveness of vitamin D supplementation for CKD patients, though recommendations remain ambiguous due to insufficient evidence on risks and benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) on dialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of vitamin D supplementation in relieving the symptoms of primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed that vitamin D significantly reduced pain in individuals with dysmenorrhea, particularly at weekly doses over 50,000 IU, regardless of treatment duration or dose interval.
population_specificity: Individuals with primary dysmenorrhea (695 participants across 8 RCTs).
effective_dosage: Average weekly dose over 50,000 IU (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Varied (some trials administered vitamin D for more or less than 70 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between antenatal depression and adverse birth outcomes among women living with HIV (WHIV) in a randomized trial of vitamin D.
results_summary: The study found no association between antenatal depression and adverse birth outcomes, including stillbirth, preterm birth, or low birth weight. Vitamin D's specific effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Pregnant women living with HIV (WHIV) on antiretroviral therapy (ART) in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between vitamin D supplementation or vitamin D status during pregnancy and congenital anomalies in the offspring.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of RCTs showed no effect of vitamin D supplementation on congenital anomalies, while one observational study found an association between low vitamin D levels and neural tube defects. Overall, the evidence was mixed and of moderate certainty.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding vitamin D supplementation to a multidomain intervention (exercise and cognitive training) would enhance cognitive improvements in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in cognition with vitamin D supplementation, either alone or as part of the multidomain intervention. The primary cognitive benefits were attributed to aerobic-resistance exercise and cognitive training, with no additional effect from vitamin D.
population_specificity: Older adults (ages 65-84) with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of active vitamin D in managing FGF23-related hypophosphatemia in a patient with advanced small cell lung cancer.
results_summary: Active vitamin D, combined with phosphate supplementation and metyrapone, partially improved serum phosphate and cortisol levels, but the cancer progressed, and FGF23 levels further increased. The study suggests monitoring hypophosphatemia-related parameters in advanced small cell lung cancer patients to prevent osteomalacia.
population_specificity: A 52-year-old patient with advanced-stage small cell lung cancer and FGF23-related hypophosphatemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between vitamin D status and the gut microbiome of pregnant women.
results_summary: The study analyzed gut microbiome and vitamin D levels in pregnant women, using statistical methods to identify associations, but specific outcomes regarding vitamin D's effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Pregnant women participating in the Vitamin D Antenatal Asthma Reduction Trial (VDAART).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary factors, including Vitamin D supplementation, were associated with arterial stiffness in pediatric populations.
results_summary: A Vitamin D supplementation trial showed protective effects on arterial stiffness measures (PWV and AIx) in adolescents, though overall findings across studies were inconsistent.
population_specificity: Pediatric population (aged 0-18 years), specifically adolescents in the Vitamin D trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to propose recommendations for achieving vitamin D sufficiency in Malaysian adults through safe sun exposure, food fortification, and supplementation.
results_summary: The study identified high-risk groups for vitamin D deficiency, recommended using serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D as a biomarker, and proposed loading doses and ongoing management strategies. It also advocated for nationwide standardization and further research.
population_specificity: Adult Malaysian population, with specific focus on high-risk groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of conducting a large randomized controlled trial to determine the effects of vitamin D supplementation on the risk of peritoneal dialysis-related peritonitis.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D supplementation (2000 IU/day) significantly increased serum 25(OH)D levels and demonstrated high retention and adherence rates, suggesting feasibility for a larger trial. However, the abstract does not provide conclusive data on peritonitis occurrence outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients receiving peritoneal dialysis who had recovered from a recent episode of peritonitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single high dose of vitamin D administered during acute pulmonary exacerbations in cystic fibrosis patients would favorably alter bone turnover markers compared to placebo.
results_summary: Participants receiving vitamin D showed significant decreases in bone turnover markers (CTX-1 and P1NP), while those on placebo had non-significant increases, suggesting vitamin D may reduce the risk of CF-related bone disease.
population_specificity: People with cystic fibrosis experiencing acute pulmonary exacerbations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of high vs. low doses of Vitamin D supplementation on placental development and morphology in pregnant women, hypothesizing that insufficient Vitamin D levels would correlate with smaller placental weight and increased vascular/inflammatory pathology.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in placental pathology between high (4400 IU/day) and low (400 IU/day) Vitamin D groups, but higher maternal serum 25(OH)D levels were associated with greater placental weight.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (n=297) at 10-14 weeks' gestational age.
study_duration: From 10-14 weeks' gestational age until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of vitamin D supplementation on the prognosis of differentiated thyroid cancer (DTC) patients post-thyroidectomy.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation was positively associated with reduced all-cause and total cancer mortality in DTC patients, suggesting it may improve survival. The study found no significant association with thyroid cancer-specific mortality.
population_specificity: 9,739 DTC patients who underwent thyroidectomy (1997-2016), with 3,238 matched pairs in the VD and control groups.
study_duration: Follow-up period was 10.7 ± 4.2 years (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether monthly vitamin D supplementation reduces the incidence of major cardiovascular events in older adults.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation was associated with a modest reduction in major cardiovascular events (hazard ratio 0.91), particularly myocardial infarction and coronary revascularization, but no significant effect on stroke. The absolute risk difference was small, and the confidence intervals included the possibility of no effect.
population_specificity: Adults aged 60-84 years in Australia, excluding those with certain medical conditions or high baseline vitamin D intake.
interactions: Potential interaction noted for participants taking cardiovascular drugs at baseline (enhanced effect).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the effectiveness of exergaming on walking in older adults and investigate factors influencing its impact.
results_summary: Exergaming interventions were more effective for walking improvements compared to control groups, with benefits maintained at follow-up. Greater benefits were observed when compared to inactive groups.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥60 years) without neurological disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of physical exercise, particularly strength-resistance training and its combination with aerobic exercise, compared to walking alone, in treating sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study found that strength-resistance training, either alone or combined with aerobic exercise, improved muscle mass, strength, and functional test times more effectively than walking alone. Frequent exercise (more than two sessions per week) also increased fat-free mass.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals experiencing sarcopenia.
effective_dosage: More than two sessions per week (frequency mentioned, but exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the minimal clinically important difference (MCID) in Berg Balance Scale (BBS) scores for early subacute stroke patients, comparing those who require walking assistance and those who do not.
results_summary: The study found that a 5-point improvement in BBS scores was a useful indicator for reducing walking assistance in early subacute stroke patients who required aid, with an AUC of 0.84 indicating good discrimination accuracy. No significant results were reported for patients who did not require assistance.
population_specificity: Early subacute stroke patients (80 participants), divided into those requiring walking assistance and those who did not.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether repetitive ankle dorsiflexion exercises using pedal switches (connected to web games vs. home appliances) could improve walking and balance performance in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The intervention group using web game-connected pedal switches showed more significant improvements in sway patterns, balance, and walking performance compared to the control group using home appliance-connected switches. The study concluded that integrating web games with pedal switches enhances exercise adherence and rehabilitation outcomes.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (n=48, 24 intervention, 24 control).
effective_dosage: Not specified (ankle dorsiflexion exercises using pedal switches).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aerobic walking and dance interventions could improve white matter integrity in healthy older adults.
results_summary: The study found that aerobic walking and social dance interventions led to positive changes in white matter integrity in late-myelinating regions, with walking also correlating with improved episodic memory performance. Cardiorespiratory fitness improvements did not correlate with white matter changes.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults aged 60-79 years (n = 180).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if sensor-derived data on daily life motor performance could improve therapy personalization and rehabilitation planning for stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found high variability in motor performance and capacity measures, with notable discrepancies between the two in some patients, suggesting objective performance data could aid in tailoring rehabilitation. However, the short recording time (average 5.03 hours) limited broader conclusions.
population_specificity: Ambulatory stroke patients (n=15, aged 59.9 ± 9.8 years, 6.5 ± 7.2 years post-stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of exercise training, including aerobic training (e.g., walking) and combined training, on reducing intermuscular adipose tissue (IMAT) in adults with chronic diseases.
results_summary: Moderate-intensity aerobic exercise (e.g., walking) and combined training effectively reduced IMAT in adults aged 18-65 with chronic diseases, particularly when associated with body weight and fat mass loss. However, in older or frail individuals, exercise may paradoxically increase IMAT accumulation.
population_specificity: Adults (age range 34.8-93.4 years) with various chronic conditions, including HIV+ individuals.
effective_dosage: Not specified (moderate-intensity aerobic training and combined training were used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dual-task walking training with and without blood flow restriction on muscle quality biomarkers, physical function, and cognitive function in older women.
results_summary: The study found that dual-task training with blood flow restriction resulted in significant improvements in muscle quality biomarkers, physical function (e.g., knee extension, walking tests), cognitive function, and psychological status compared to control and dual-task training alone.
population_specificity: Healthy older women (mean age 62.9 ± 3.1 years).
effective_dosage: Walking on a treadmill at 45% of heart rate reserve for 20 minutes per session, three sessions per week. Blood flow restriction was applied at 50% of arterial occlusion pressure, increased by 10% every 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate motor and non-motor factors associated with sit-to-stand performance in people with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS), including walking speed, cognitive function, and fatigue.
results_summary: The study found that sit-to-stand performance was significantly correlated with walking speed, cognitive function, and fatigue, suggesting these factors should be considered in rehabilitation interventions for PwMS.
population_specificity: 88 individuals with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of aquatic therapy versus land-based exercises on lower limb disability in post-stroke patients.
results_summary: Aquatic therapy improved balance, walking speed, and mobility more effectively than land-based exercises, with significant standardized mean differences reported.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients with lower limb disability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of surgical versus conservative treatment for unstable fragility fractures of the pelvis (FFP) in terms of early mobilization, survival, and functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in survival rates or walking ability at final follow-up between surgical and conservative treatments. Surgical treatment enabled earlier mobilization in type III FFP, but type IVb FFP patients achieved early mobilization even without surgery.
population_specificity: 64 patients with unstable type III and IV FFP who could move and transfer themselves before injury and had ≥5 mm displacement of the posterior component.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the extent to which outdoor mobility is incorporated into rehabilitation interventions after hip fracture and to synthesize evidence for their effectiveness on ambulatory ability and falls-related self-efficacy.
results_summary: The study found limited and conflicting evidence on the effect of outdoor mobility interventions on walking ability and self-efficacy after hip fracture, with poor reporting of intervention details and underlying evidence quality. No clear benefit could be attributed to outdoor mobility components.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from hip fracture in community-based settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of overground and treadmill gait training on gait symmetry, functional mobility, and kinesiophobia in patients with lower limb burn injuries.
results_summary: Treadmill gait training was more effective than overground training in improving functional mobility and reducing kinesiophobia. Both training modes improved gait symmetry, velocity, and cadence in patients with lower limb burn injuries.
population_specificity: Patients with lower limb burn injuries (n=28).
effective_dosage: Gait training intensity (speed and duration) was determined by patient tolerance, performed 5 days per week.
study_duration: From hospital admission to discharge (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining walking training with tDCS improves walking metrics (speed, cadence, step length), reduces falls and freezing, and enhances social participation in people with Parkinson's disease, compared to walking training alone or no/sham intervention.
results_summary: The study found that adding tDCS to walking training provided negligible additional benefits over walking training alone for walking speed, step length, or cadence. No evidence was available to assess effects on freezing of gait, falls, or social participation.
population_specificity: Ambulatory adults with a clinical diagnosis of Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: Training sessions lasted 30 to 60 minutes, conducted two to three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the 12-month technical and clinical outcomes of the Gore Excluder Iliac Branch Endoprosthesis (IBE) for treating aorto-iliac aneurysms, including its impact on walking ability as measured by the Walking Impairment Questionnaire (WIQ).
results_summary: WIQ scores initially decreased at 30 days but returned to baseline values by 12 months, indicating temporary impairment followed by recovery. The device showed satisfactory primary patency (91.3%) and low re-intervention rates, with stable quality-of-life and erectile function scores.
population_specificity: Primarily male patients (97%) with a median age of 70.0 years, treated for aorto-iliac aneurysms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of customized vestibular rehabilitation (VR) plus standard canalith repositioning maneuver (CRM) on dynamic gait measures in adults with unilateral posterior canal benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).
results_summary: The study found that six weeks of customized VR combined with standard CRM significantly improved dynamic gait measures (gait duration, stride velocity, turning duration, and steps while turning) compared to standard CRM alone. The experimental group showed better balance and gait outcomes, with statistically significant improvements (p < 0.05).
population_specificity: Adults (aged 50.71±9.88 and 54.36±8.55 years) with unilateral posterior canal BPPV.
effective_dosage: Customized VR plus standard CRM for six weeks (experimental group) vs. standard CRM for two weeks (control group).
study_duration: Six weeks for the experimental group, two weeks for the control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the pathophysiology, diagnosis, and treatment effectiveness of communicating chronic hydrocephalus (CCH), particularly its impact on walking and other neurological functions.
results_summary: The study found that CCH primarily impairs walking, along with cognitive and sphincter disorders, and that early treatment with a permanent CSF shunt leads to significant motor improvement (75-90%).
population_specificity: Patients over 60 years of age with communicating chronic hydrocephalus (CCH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify intrinsic and extrinsic risk factors for falls during pregnancy and explore possible prevention strategies.
results_summary: The study identified 13 intrinsic and 11 extrinsic risk factors for falls during pregnancy, including factors like slippery floors, age, and hyperemesis gravidarum. Physical activity, maternity support belts, and education were suggested as potential prevention strategies.
population_specificity: Pregnant women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the performance of QUICK TAPE and traditional low-Dye taping in providing support and off-loading for individuals with moderate-to-severe pes planus.
results_summary: Both taping methods significantly increased arch height index and altered plantar loading during walking compared to barefoot, with reduced force-time integral in the forefoot and increased under the toes. Participants found both tapings more supportive than barefoot, with QUICK TAPE preferred for comfort over low-Dye.
population_specificity: 20 healthy participants (40 feet) with moderate-to-severe pes planus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of exercise interventions, including walking, on improving physical functioning and quality of life in patients receiving HSCT.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed statistically significant improvements in 6-minute walking distance, lower extremity strength, and global quality of life for patients receiving exercise interventions, including walking.
population_specificity: Adult patients receiving haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits of enriched garden interventions, including walking stimulation, on cognitive function, independence, and fall risk in nursing home residents with dementia.
results_summary: The enriched garden group showed significant improvements in cognitive function (MMSE), activities of daily living (ADL), and fall risk measures (TUG and unipodal stance) compared to the conventional sensory garden and control groups.
population_specificity: Nursing home residents with dementia, independent for walking, and without severe dementia or behavioral troubles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether total knee arthroplasty affects dynamic stability during stair negotiation in patients with severe osteoarthritis compared to asymptomatic controls.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in dynamic stability between patients (pre- and post-surgery) and asymptomatic controls during stair gait. Additionally, patients' stability did not improve significantly one year after surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage knee osteoarthritis scheduled for unilateral total knee arthroplasty and asymptomatic controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the factors, surgical treatment methods, and clinical outcomes of internal fixation failure in intertrochanteric and subtrochanteric fractures, focusing on restoring walking function.
results_summary: The study found that both arthroplasty and internal fixation revision effectively restored walking function, with significant improvements in Harris hip scores postoperatively. Arthroplasty showed shorter operative times and less blood loss compared to revision, but both methods yielded comparable long-term functional outcomes.
population_specificity: 18 patients (10 males, 8 females) aged 38-92 years with internal fixation failure of intertrochanteric or subtrochanteric fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of the Intel RealSense T265 device for tracking natural human head motion during walking in various environments compared to gold-standard methods.
results_summary: The study found that the T265 device performed most accurately for slow to normal walking speeds in small- to medium-sized environments, though its suitability depends on the specific application.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied general human population engaging in walking activities).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effect of wearing a lumbosacral orthosis (LSO) alongside routine physical therapy versus physical therapy alone on walking complexity in individuals with nonspecific chronic low back pain (CLBP).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in walking complexity between the group receiving LSO plus physical therapy and the group receiving physical therapy alone at any evaluation period, suggesting LSO did not alter emergent walking behavior.
population_specificity: Individuals with nonspecific chronic low back pain (CLBP)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the efficacy of robotic gait training (using the G-EO system) in improving gait, reducing fall risk, and assessing long-term effects in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that robotic gait training combined with traditional therapy could improve gait and reduce fall risk in subacute stroke patients, with additional assessments on step length, asymmetry, and functional status.
population_specificity: Elderly subacute stroke patients (n=152)
effective_dosage: 20 treatment sessions (3 sessions per week), with 30 min of traditional therapy and 20 min of robotic training per session for the intervention group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of aerobic exercise (walking/jogging) on cognitive performance in older adults at increased risk of dementia and explore the biological mechanisms behind these effects.
results_summary: The study is designed to assess whether aerobic exercise improves cognitive performance and whether these benefits persist after a 1-year behavioral support program, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 50-80 years at elevated risk of dementia due to genetic and/or cardiovascular risk factors.
effective_dosage: Three supervised walking/jogging sessions per week.
study_duration: 6 months of exercise intervention followed by 1 year of behavioral support.

study_goal: The researchers were exploring the potential of oncoproteogenomics and glycoproteomics to improve precision oncology and immunotherapy, not studying Walking.
results_summary: The abstract discusses advancements in molecular-assisted precision oncology, including the use of tumor-specific peptides and glycoproteomics, but does not mention Walking.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on cancer research, not Walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between apathy, depressive symptoms, and discordance between self-reported functional limitations and performance-based physical functioning (including walking speed) in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that older adults, on average, overestimated their daily functioning compared to performance tests, with negative emotions (rather than apathy) linked to underestimation of physical capacity. Further research is needed to explore whether addressing this discordance preserves physical functioning and if tailored approaches are needed for those with apathy or depression.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 70.48 years, 65% female, 73% depressed) from the NESDO cohort study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of exercise training, including walking, on improving walking capacity in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: Exercise training, including walking, was found to improve walking capacity in patients with PAD, alongside medical therapies that reduce major adverse cardiovascular and limb events.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD), often with coexistent coronary or cerebrovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a progressive multicomponent exercise program on functional capacity, fitness, quality of life, dual-task performance, and physiological variables in elderly adults.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a structured 27-week multicomponent exercise program divided into three phases, with primary outcomes focusing on functional capacity, fitness, quality of life, and physiological variables. Secondary outcomes include physical activity levels, motivation for exercise, and anthropometric measurements.
population_specificity: Elderly adults with reduced functional reserve.
effective_dosage: Not specified (program involves progressive phases of exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the biological mechanisms by which walking exercise improves walking ability in people with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and how these mechanisms differ from those in people without PAD.
results_summary: Walking exercise improved treadmill walking time in PAD patients but also increased muscle denervation markers. Exercise did not consistently improve mitochondrial activity or capillary density in PAD patients, though it may enhance plasma nitrite levels, potentially improving muscle perfusion.
population_specificity: Older individuals with peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review advancements in medical revascularization for peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and explore potential novel approaches for therapeutic angiogenesis and arteriogenesis.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that PAD causes significant morbidity and mortality, with limited benefits from current medical therapies. While some treatments like anticoagulants and lipid-lowering agents reduce major cardiovascular and limb events, chronic limb ischemia remains resistant to medical therapy. Experimental approaches, including angiogenic cytokines and cell therapy, have shown early promise but lack significant benefit in larger randomized trials.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of electromyostimulation (EMS) on muscle strength and function in sarcopenic patients during a 4-week inpatient medical rehabilitation program.
results_summary: The study found that EMS significantly improved muscle function (chair rise test) and strength (leg extension) compared to standard rehabilitation. Whole-body EMS showed greater functional and strength improvements than part-body EMS or the control group.
population_specificity: Elderly, sedentary individuals diagnosed with sarcopenia (134 patients, 55.7 ± 7.9 years, 25.4% female).
effective_dosage: Six 20-minute training sessions per week with superimposed EMS (whole-body or part-body).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether motivational interviewing increases time spent walking at 12 months in community-dwelling people recovering from hip fracture compared to a control group receiving dietary advice.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results in the abstract, but it assessed daily walking time and secondary outcomes like psychological function, mobility, community participation, and falls at multiple time points. The process evaluation also examined intervention fidelity and contextual factors.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged ≥65 years, living independently within 6 months of hip fracture discharge, able to walk independently and communicate in English.
effective_dosage: 10 telephone-based sessions (8 weekly and 2 booster) of motivational interviewing or dietary advice.
study_duration: 16 weeks (with follow-up assessments up to 52 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether multimodal prehabilitation, including walking, improves functional capacity (FC) in prediabetic patients undergoing colorectal cancer surgery.
results_summary: Prehabilitation significantly improved FC before surgery (Adjusted OR 2.42) and attenuated FC loss after surgery, especially in prediabetic patients. Prediabetes itself was not a significant predictor of FC improvement after adjustments.
population_specificity: Prediabetic and non-prediabetic patients undergoing colorectal cancer surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (6-minute walking test used for assessment).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated; assessments occurred at baseline, 24h before surgery, and 4 weeks after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of the timed 25-foot walk (T25FW) as a clinical outcome measure in multiple sclerosis and assess factors associated with its change.
results_summary: The T25FW demonstrated excellent test-retest reliability (ICC = 0.98) and was associated with disability progression, age, disease type, and duration. Changes in T25FW were more likely to precede changes in EDSS, supporting its predictive validity.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis from the Multiple Sclerosis Outcome Assessments Consortium (MSOAC) Placebo Database.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Gap Balancing (GB) versus Measured Resection (MR) techniques on early clinical and radiological outcomes of Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA), including gait parameters related to walking.
results_summary: The study found that GB and MR techniques had similar effects on early clinical results, but GB provided better knee flexion in early postoperative gait. No significant differences were observed in spatiotemporal gait parameters (walking speed, step length, single support time) or WOMAC scores between the groups.
population_specificity: 99 patients (99 knees) who underwent unilateral TKA, with comparable demographic and clinical data (mean age ~55 years).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical techniques compared, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical and nerve conduction study parameters to predict outcomes in children with acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) and acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN), focusing on achieving independent walking.
