results_summary: AMAN was associated with faster progression, greater peak disability, prolonged hospital stay, and delayed walking. Asymmetric nerve involvement and prolonged ulnar F-wave latencies in AMAN patients were linked to delayed walking.
population_specificity: Children with acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) and acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN).
study_duration: Follow-up until independent walking (time varied, with early walking defined as within 60 days and delayed as after 60 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of riociguat in treating chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH), not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that riociguat improved hemodynamic parameters, increased 6-minute walking distance, and reduced dyspnea scores in CTEPH patients, with no serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH).

study_goal: To determine if a community-based cardiac rehabilitation program improves walking ability, quality of life, and health behavior in patients with intermittent claudication compared to usual care.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a 37% improvement in maximum walking distance at six and 12 months, along with positive effects on physical activity, quality of life, and healthy diet, though pain-free walking distance and smoking did not show statistically significant improvements.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication undergoing non-operative management.
effective_dosage: 12 weeks of exercise training, pedometer use, health education, and text messages.
study_duration: 12 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at six and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supervised exercise therapy (SET) improves cardiovascular health (measured by blood pressure and heart rate during exercise) and walking performance in people with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: SET significantly reduced systolic blood pressure, pulse pressure, and heart rate during exercise compared to the control group, and these improvements correlated with better walking performance (6-minute walk distance, maximal treadmill walking distance, and WIQ distance score). Diastolic blood pressure did not show significant changes.
population_specificity: 176 participants with PAD (67 ± 9 years; 41% female, 65% Black).
effective_dosage: SET group: 3× weekly supervised exercise; control group: 1× weekly health lectures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of peripheral and respiratory muscle strength training combined with conventional physical therapy on respiratory muscle strength, functional capacity, and quality of life in CABG patients during the immediate postoperative period.
results_summary: The intervention group showed less reduction in inspiratory muscle strength and improved pain and vitality perception compared to the control group, though both groups experienced reduced functional capacity and expiratory muscle strength post-CABG.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery.
effective_dosage: One session per day for 5 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how acute and chronic exercise, including low-intensity walking, affects postprandial glucose and insulin excursions in individuals at risk for or with Type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that walking and other forms of exercise improve postprandial hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia, contributing to better glycemic control and insulin sensitivity. Timing of exercise around meals and post-exercise nutrition also influences these benefits.
population_specificity: Individuals at risk for or diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical characteristics of frail patients hospitalized for acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF), focusing on functional decline, including walking ability, using the Kihon Checklist.
results_summary: The study found that worsening walking ability during hospitalization increased with frailty status (27.5% in frail, 21.8% in prefrail, and 8.9% in non-frail patients). Frailty was associated with older age, prior HF hospitalization, higher brain natriuretic peptide levels, and prior cerebrovascular accidents.
population_specificity: 1061 patients (median age 81 years, 50.0% men) hospitalized for ADHF in Kochi Prefecture, Japan.
study_duration: Data collected between June 2017 and December 2019 (hospitalization period not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the tolerability of physiotherapy treatment, including walking training, in COVID-19 patients undergoing hip surgery compared to non-COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found that physiotherapy, including walking training, was well-tolerated in COVID-19 patients, with only mild breathing difficulty (Borg scale 1.3 vs. 0.6 in non-COVID patients). Walking recovery was lower in COVID-19 patients (44.4%) compared to non-COVID patients (63%), but the difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients with COVID-19 and hip fracture (n=9) compared to non-COVID-19 patients with hip fracture (n=27).

study_goal: To investigate the effects of an 8-form Tai Chi exercise on physical function, fear of falling, and depression in pre-frail elderly individuals living in senior communities.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in physical function (lower limb strength and gait speed), fear of falling, and depression after 8 weeks of Tai Chi intervention compared to the control group. While some benefits were observed at 4 weeks, the full effects were more pronounced by the 8th week.
population_specificity: Pre-frail elderly individuals living in senior communities.
effective_dosage: Three times per week, 60 minutes each session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term effectiveness of the Walking Away program, a group-based behavioral physical activity intervention, with or without mHealth support, in increasing ambulatory activity among individuals at risk of type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: At 12 months, the Walking Away Plus (WAP) group showed a modest increase in ambulatory activity (547 steps/day) compared to control, but this effect was not sustained at 48 months. The Walking Alone (WA) group showed no significant difference from control at either time point, apart from small reductions in body weight (~1 kg).
population_specificity: Individuals at risk of type 2 diabetes (nondiabetic hyperglycemia), median age 61 years, 49% women, 28% ethnic minorities.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included group education, annual support, and mHealth components like tailored text messages and phone calls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN) alters walking (gait) patterns and contributes to balance impairments and falls in diabetes patients.
results_summary: The study found that DPN causes significant gait impairments, including altered walking speed, step length, and joint motion, which increase falls risk. Muscle weakness and delayed neuromuscular responses further exacerbate balance issues, particularly in DPN patients.
population_specificity: Diabetes patients, with a focus on those with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of powered exoskeleton training on cardiovascular function and gait performance in patients with neurological impairments.
results_summary: The study systematically reviewed literature to assess the impact of powered exoskeleton training, suggesting it may combat physical deconditioning and improve fitness and health in neurologically impaired patients.
population_specificity: Patients with neurological impairments experiencing physical deconditioning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of nature video viewing during isometric exercise (wall squats) to explore a practical application of green exercise in urban settings.
results_summary: Nature video viewing during exercise was associated with better affective responses and improved heart rate variability metrics, suggesting enhanced psychophysiological benefits compared to the control condition.
population_specificity: 18 male subjects
effective_dosage: Not specified (nature video played during 2-minute exercise and recovery periods)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether higher walking activity levels during early rehabilitation after total hip arthroplasty (THA) affect periprosthetic bone environment and evaluate the safety and efficacy of such activity.
results_summary: Higher walking activity accelerated bone remodeling and increased stress shielding but did not significantly improve functional recovery. No adverse events were reported, and prosthetic stability was maintained in both groups.
population_specificity: 22 patients with advanced osteonecrosis of the femoral head who underwent primary unilateral THA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of walking interventions, including supervised treadmill exercise and home-based walking programs, on functional outcomes in individuals with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: Supervised treadmill exercise improved 6-minute walk distance by 30 to 35 meters, while effective home-based walking interventions improved it by 42 to 53 meters, both representing clinically meaningful changes. Behavioral methods, including coaching, were essential for successful home-based programs.
population_specificity: Individuals with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD), particularly those aged 50 years and older, with a focus on those experiencing functional decline.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions included supervised treadmill exercise and home-based walking programs with behavioral coaching).
study_duration: Not specified (abstract does not detail intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a rare case of aggressive vertebral hemangioma causing walking difficulty and sensory disturbances, highlighting the need for a multidisciplinary treatment approach.
results_summary: The study found that an aggressive vertebral hemangioma caused severe spinal cord compression, leading to walking difficulty and sensory disturbances in a 68-year-old female. Treatment involved a combined endovascular and surgical approach, emphasizing the rarity and complexity of such cases.
population_specificity: 68-year-old female with progressive walking difficulty and sensory disturbances in lower extremities due to aggressive vertebral hemangioma.

study_goal: To examine whether providing a cane to ambulatory individuals with chronic stroke improves walking and social participation.
results_summary: Use of a cane improved walking speed only when participants walked with the cane, but no lasting improvements were observed when walking without it after one month. The study found no rehabilitative effect on walking outcomes without the cane.
population_specificity: Ambulatory individuals with chronic stroke (mean age ~68-69 years).
effective_dosage: Provision of a single-point cane (no specific dosage mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare long-term outcomes (walking ability, shoe fit, and additional surgeries) between open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) versus nonoperative treatment for displaced intra-articular calcaneal fractures.
results_summary: At 60 months, ORIF showed no significant difference in walking difficulty, shoe fit, or functional scores compared to nonoperative treatment, but required more additional surgeries.
population_specificity: Patients aged over 16 with closed displaced intra-articular calcaneal fractures, excluding those with fibular impingement, vascular disease, or other major limb injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of shoe-stiffening inserts on lower extremity kinematics in individuals with first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint osteoarthritis (OA) during walking.
results_summary: The shoe-stiffening inserts significantly reduced first MTP joint maximum dorsiflexion and ankle joint maximum plantarflexion while increasing knee joint maximum flexion and total excursion compared to sham inserts. These changes suggest altered lower extremity joint kinematics during walking, potentially explaining clinical effectiveness in treating first MTP joint OA.
population_specificity: 48 individuals (24 male, 24 female; mean age 57.8 ± 10.5 years) with radiographically confirmed first MTP joint OA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence and clinical characteristics of physical frailty in COPD patients with chronic respiratory failure and assess the usefulness of gait speed (via SPPB and TUG) as a screening tool for frailty.
results_summary: The study found that physical frailty affects a large proportion of COPD patients and is associated with worse clinical status. Gait speed showed potential as a simple screening tool for frailty in this population.
population_specificity: COPD patients with chronic respiratory failure referred to home-based pulmonary rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of individualized home-centered activity-based therapy (including walking) as an adjunct to institutional physiotherapy in children with spastic diplegic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that home-centered activity-based therapy was safe and feasible but did not result in significant improvements in walking performance (6MWT scores) over 6 months compared to institutional physiotherapy alone. The median changes in walking distance were minimal and similar between groups.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-12 years with spastic diplegic cerebral palsy (Gross Motor Function Classification System scores II-III) and no fixed lower-limb contractures or recent botulinum toxin injections/surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (activity-based therapy included walking, standing, squatting, climbing stairs, kicking a ball, dancing, and riding a tricycle/bicycle).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the incidence and severity of physiological abnormalities or adverse events during physical therapy interventions, including walking, in ICU patients after cardiac surgery.
results_summary: Walking was associated with a 40% incidence of physiological abnormalities or adverse events, primarily hemodynamic changes, but only a small fraction resulted in mild or moderate harm. The presence of comorbidities was linked to these events.
population_specificity: Adult patients in the postoperative period of cardiac surgery admitted to the ICU of a university hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intensive perioperative pulmonary rehabilitation (including walking exercises) improves exercise capacity in patients undergoing lung resection for non-small cell lung cancer.
results_summary: The study found that pulmonary rehabilitation significantly improved exercise capacity at 6 months post-surgery (+48.9 meters vs. -7.5 meters in controls) and reduced exercise tolerance impairment at 1 month post-surgery (-3.0 meters vs. -30.1 meters in controls). No other significant differences between groups were observed.
population_specificity: Patients referred for lung resection from a local lung cancer multidisciplinary team.
study_duration: Preoperative and postoperative periods (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise interventions, including walking, improve health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in stroke or transient ischemic attack survivors.
results_summary: Exercise interventions, including walking, showed small to moderate beneficial effects on HRQoL, particularly in physical and mental health domains, with the most effective interventions involving at least 150 minutes per week, lasting 12 weeks, and including resistance training. Effects appeared to diminish at longer-term follow-up.
population_specificity: Stroke or transient ischemic attack survivors (n=1836 patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of apalutamide on pain and fatigue, specifically its interference with walking ability, in patients with metastatic castration-sensitive prostate cancer.
results_summary: The study found that apalutamide significantly delayed the time to deterioration in pain interfering with walking ability (28.7 months vs. 20.2 months with placebo). No significant difference in fatigue was observed between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic castration-sensitive prostate cancer receiving androgen deprivation therapy.
study_duration: Median follow-up times were 19 to 22 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a walking school bus (WSB) program on child self-efficacy (SE), parent SE, and parent outcome expectations (OE) related to active commuting to school.
results_summary: The WSB intervention led to statistically significant increases in child SE (0.12 points), parent SE (0.11 points), and parent OE (0.09 points) compared to controls. The results supported the hypothesis that the WSB improves behavioral constructs associated with active commuting.
population_specificity: Third- to fifth-grade students and their parents (n = 418 child-parent dyads) from racially diverse, low-income populations in Houston, TX, and Seattle, WA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of immediate weight-bearing (IWB) and range of motion (ROM) exercises versus traditional non-weight-bearing (NWB) and immobilization in a cast following ORIF of unstable ankle fractures.
results_summary: The study proposed to investigate whether IWB and ROM exercises could yield comparable or better functional outcomes (measured by OMAS) and complication rates compared to NWB and immobilization, with emerging evidence suggesting potential benefits but higher wound-related complications.
population_specificity: Adult patients with unstable ankle fractures (lateral malleolar, bimalleolar, trimalleolar with or without syndesmotic injury) presenting to three trauma units, excluding skeletal immaturity and tibial plafond fractures.
effective_dosage: Immediate weight-bearing in a walking boot and ROM exercises within 24 hours post-surgery.
study_duration: 6 weeks (comparison group had NWB and immobilization for 6 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of success for pulmonary rehabilitation, including walking tests, in patients with Interstitial Lung Diseases (ILD).
results_summary: Patients showed improvements in walking distance, dyspnoea, and arterial blood gases after rehabilitation, but benefits were reduced in those needing oxygen therapy and not maintained long-term.
population_specificity: 240 in-patients with ILD (110 idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, 106 other ILD, 24 undetermined ILD).
study_duration: Not specified (retrospective evaluation over 10 years, follow-up at ~10.3 months)

study_goal: To determine if initial walking speed influences dual-task performance after a walking intervention, hypothesizing that slow walking speed limits executive resource availability for gait control.
results_summary: Single-task walking improved in both groups, but the study suggests that individuals who walk slowly may struggle to improve dual-task walking ability.
population_specificity: Adults six-months post-stroke with walking impairment.
effective_dosage: Twenty sessions of 30-minute treadmill walking over 10 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and summarize existing knowledge about preoperative exercise strategies, including walking, for abdominal cancer patients.
results_summary: Walking was the most common form of aerobic exercise (n=13) in the reviewed studies, often combined with resistance exercises. Most interventions were performed at moderate intensity, 2-3 times/week, for 30-60 minutes per session.
population_specificity: Abdominal cancer patients, primarily colorectal cancer (n=14).
study_duration: Less than 4 weeks for most studies (n=11).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an intervention promoting leisure-time walking and a healthy diet during antenatal care to mitigate negative outcomes of a sedentary lifestyle and unhealthy diet during pregnancy.
results_summary: The intervention increased leisure-time walking during the second and third trimesters, tripling the proportion of pregnant women achieving the recommended 150 minutes per week of walking. It also reduced the risk of consuming soft drinks and processed cookies in the third trimester.
population_specificity: Pregnant women receiving antenatal care in health care units following the Family Health Strategy model (intervention group) versus the traditional model (control group).
study_duration: Each trimester of pregnancy (approximately 9 months total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between sarcopenia and urine pH in the elderly, focusing on factors like walking ability, strength, and metabolic acidosis.
results_summary: The study found that the sarcopenia group had significantly lower urine pH (mean pH = 5.5) compared to the nonsarcopenia group (mean pH = 6.2), suggesting a potential link between metabolic acidosis and sarcopenia. Urine pH, age, and exercise habits were independently associated with sarcopenia.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (n = 123, mean age = 81.7 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether individuals with transfemoral amputations classified as MFCL level K2 could benefit from using a microprocessor-controlled knee (MPK) and appropriate foot compared to a non-microprocessor-controlled knee (NMPK).
results_summary: The study found statistically significant and clinically meaningful improvements in gait performance, safety, and self-reported measures when using the MPK + 1M10 foot combination, with scores approaching those of individuals at a higher functional level (K3).
population_specificity: Ten individuals (mean age 63 ± 9 years) with unilateral transfemoral amputation due to vascular conditions, designated as MFCL level K2.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (prosthetic intervention, not a supplement).
study_duration: 6 months per intervention (3 months acclimation, 3 months take-home trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of exoskeleton-assisted walking (EAW) on pulmonary function parameters, 6-minute walk test (6MWT), and lower extremity motor score (LEMS) in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) compared to conventional training.
results_summary: The study found that EAW significantly improved forced vital capacity (FVC), predicted FVC%, and forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) compared to conventional training. Additionally, robotic exoskeleton assistance facilitated walking in SCI individuals.
population_specificity: Individuals with lower thoracic neurological level of spinal cord injury (SCI).
effective_dosage: 16 sessions of 50-60 minutes training (4 days/week, 4 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a pedometer-based walking program could reduce inflammation markers (CRP, IL-6, TNF-α) and improve cardiovascular health in sedentary young men with risk factors.
results_summary: The pedometer group significantly increased daily steps (from ~5,000 to ~10,000) and showed reduced inflammation markers (CRP, IL-6, TNF-α) and improved lipid profiles, while the control group showed no changes.
population_specificity: Sedentary young men (20-40 years) with ≥2 cardiovascular risk factors and <5,000 daily steps.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of physically active lessons on movement behaviors, cognitive function, and academic performance in elementary schoolchildren.
results_summary: The intervention reduced sedentary behavior, increased walking and light physical activity, and improved cognitive performance (fewer errors and faster response times in the go/no go test), but had no impact on academic performance.
population_specificity: 61 second-year elementary school students from a public school in Brazil (34 intervention, 27 control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare early outcomes and gait analysis of total hip arthroplasty (THA) using the mini posterior approach (MPA) and the SuperPATH approach.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in surgical outcomes between the two approaches, but the SuperPATH group had less pain, higher physical function, and improved quality of life postoperatively. Gait analysis showed nonsignificant differences between the two approaches at 6 weeks follow-up.
population_specificity: 44 patients who underwent THA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of interventions designed to promote physical activity, including walking, in people with neuromuscular diseases (NMDs) compared to no intervention or alternative interventions.
results_summary: The review found limited and low-certainty evidence on the effectiveness of physical activity interventions, with mixed results on walking duration and quality of life. No evidence suggested increased risk of serious adverse events, but reporting was incomplete.
population_specificity: Adults with inherited or acquired neuromuscular diseases (NMDs), including diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN) and spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of neuromuscular exercises versus quadriceps exercises in alleviating pain and improving function in patients with knee osteoarthritis, while exploring psychosocial benefits.
results_summary: The study found that both exercise types improved pain, function, and psychosocial outcomes, with measurements taken pre-, during, and post-exercise. Walking function was assessed via the 6-min walk test and timed up & go test, showing positive effects.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥50 years with osteoarthritic knee pain.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise programs were supervised and video-linked).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the functional outcomes of IVIg and PE treatments in GBS patients using comprehensive scales that assess basic activities of daily living, including walking capability.
results_summary: Both IVIg and PE treatments showed comparable functional outcomes, with significant improvements in motor sub-scores and overall FIM scores, as well as a mean improvement in GDS. No significant differences were found between the two treatments in terms of functional recovery.
population_specificity: 70 individuals with Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), 39 treated with PE and 31 with IVIg.
study_duration: Average of 61 days in rehabilitation department (total duration not specified for treatments alone).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare physical activity and sedentary behavior between home-based and hospital-based geriatric rehabilitation patients, focusing on walking and related measures.
results_summary: Home-based patients showed significantly higher physical activity levels (e.g., walking duration, steps) compared to hospital-based patients, even after matching for baseline function. Sedentary behaviors were similar, though home-based patients spent less time lying down.
population_specificity: Geriatric rehabilitation inpatients (mean age ~81-83 years, mixed sex, varying baseline physical function).
study_duration: 1 week of accelerometer wear, with follow-up at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effects of a single session of tDCS using various electrode montages on poststroke walking performance.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of active tDCS montages compared to sham, but personalized tDCS may improve fastest comfortable gait speed, paretic step ratio, and paretic propulsion. Responses were highly variable, suggesting individual differences in neuropathology influence outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic stroke (n = 16)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of neuromuscular training (including backward walking) on knee proprioception following ACL injury compared to other therapies.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent effects of neuromuscular training on proprioception, with very low certainty of evidence due to methodological limitations and heterogeneity in interventions. No clear optimal training method was identified.
population_specificity: 327 individuals with ACL reconstruction (ACLR).
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied interventions included whole body vibration therapy, Nintendo-Wii-Fit training, balance training, sport-specific exercises, backward walking, etc.).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the completeness, accuracy, and clinical outcomes of the BOFAS registry for ankle arthrodesis, focusing on patient-reported outcomes related to walking, pain, and social interaction.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant reductions in pain and improvements in walking/standing ability and social interaction by 12 months post-surgery, though data completeness declined over time.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥18 years in the UK who underwent ankle arthrodesis between 2014 and 2019.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether L-arginine supplementation could mitigate the adverse cardiovascular effects of walking outside under traffic-related air pollution (TRAP) in adults with elevated blood pressure.
results_summary: The study found that L-arginine supplementation significantly reduced resting and ambulatory blood pressure during outdoor walking under TRAP, with no substantial changes in inflammatory biomarkers or ST-segment levels. The intervention was safe and well-tolerated.
population_specificity: 118 adults with elevated blood pressure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance effects of periodized carbohydrate restriction in highly adapted endurance-trained athletes.
results_summary: The study found that training with low muscle glycogen may stimulate mitochondrial biogenesis and metabolic adaptations, but chronic carbohydrate restriction can compromise training quality, particularly peak interval intensities. A meta-analysis was conducted to assess the overall performance effect of periodized CHO restriction in endurance athletes.
population_specificity: Highly adapted endurance-trained athletes (females and males with a demonstrated VO2 max).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of endurance training under hypoxic and normoxic conditions on fatigue, mobility, and spasticity in MS patients during inpatient rehabilitation.
results_summary: Fatigue improved significantly in all groups, with faster improvements in groups receiving endurance training. Spasticity scores were lower in endurance training groups, and only the hypoxic group showed significant improvement in walking endurance.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) undergoing inpatient rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (endurance training duration and frequency implied but not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare walking performance between adolescents with varying degrees of scoliosis and healthy peers, examining foot posture and gait characteristics.
results_summary: Moderate and severe scoliosis significantly affected walking performance, including asymmetrical gait and altered plantar pressure, while mild scoliosis showed no significant differences from healthy controls.
population_specificity: 96 adolescents (64 with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis and 32 healthy controls) in China.
study_duration: Cross-sectional study conducted from April 2020 to October 2020.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether treatments for age-related macular degeneration (AMD) could reduce patients' risk of falls and improve mobility.
results_summary: The study found limited and inconsistent data on the relationship between AMD treatments and falls/mobility, with most outcomes having moderate to serious risk of bias and no standardized measurement tools.
population_specificity: Patients with age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prolonged release-fampridine improves gait pattern and walking capacity in patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Prolonged release-fampridine increased knee flexion during the swing phase and reduced mechanical external work, suggesting improvements in gait mechanics. However, the clinical relevance of these changes for walking capacity and other functional variables requires further investigation.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (24 responders, aged 46 ± 10 years, Expanded Disability Status Scale: 4.25[4-5]).
study_duration: 6 weeks per treatment period (crossover design with a 2-week washout).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize how ambulatory function (walking ability) is assessed and conceptualized in studies of spinal metastases treatment.
results_summary: The study found wide variation in how ambulatory function is defined and measured, with most studies relying on medical records and dichotomized outcomes (e.g., ambulatory vs. non-ambulatory). Few prospective studies used quantitative measures to assess walking ability.
population_specificity: Adult patients receiving operative or non-operative treatment for spinal metastases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a community-wide intervention (CWI) on frailty prevention and functional health, including the impact of walking ≥150 min/week.
results_summary: The study found no significant overall effect on frailty prevalence but showed benefits in functional health for subgroups, including those walking ≥150 min/week (3.9 percentage point improvement in district A). Awareness of the intervention was significantly higher in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 65-84 years in Ota City, Tokyo, Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize new rehabilitation techniques for improving balance, gait, and other symptoms in patients with multiple sclerosis over the past 5 years.
results_summary: The study found that neuromotor rehabilitation, physical exercise, rhythmic auditory stimulation, gait robot training, and exergaming are effective for balance and walking disorders in MS patients. Physical exercise also positively impacted fatigue management.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis experiencing locomotor impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of a Vojta locomotion reflex program compared to standard therapy for improving short-term automatic postural control and walking in people with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The Vojta intervention showed significant improvements in balance (Berg Balance Scale and Tandem test) compared to standard therapy, while both interventions improved walking performance (10m Walk test). Core activation was associated with better balance outcomes in the Vojta group.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (N=21) who could walk 100m but could not maintain a 30-second tandem stance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the temporal dynamics of walking behavior, including sudden behavioral gains and losses, and identify early warning signals for such changes.
results_summary: The study found that walking behavior exhibits discontinuous changes, with participants experiencing an average of six sudden gains or losses. Critical fluctuations in walking behavior were positively associated with subsequent sudden behavioral losses, suggesting potential early warning signals.
population_specificity: 151 young adults with overweight or obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cognitive impairment affects adherence and performance in a pedometer-based walking intervention for dialysis patients.
results_summary: Participants with worse cognitive function screening results had lower adherence, achieved fewer weekly goals, and showed smaller improvements in steps, physical performance, and self-reported physical function compared to those without impairment. The intervention was less effective for those with cognitive impairment, suggesting a need for tailored approaches.
population_specificity: Dialysis patients with varying levels of cognitive function (unimpaired, ambiguous impairment, mild cognitive impairment).
effective_dosage: Weekly activity goals (specific step count not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a whole-body vibration training program on quadriceps muscle strength, walking distance in the 6MWT, respiratory muscle strength, and quality of life in adult kidney transplant recipients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between groups in quadriceps muscle strength, thickness, or inspiratory muscle strength, but observed moderate to large effect sizes for these outcomes. Both groups improved in the Sit-to-Stand Test, but no superiority was noted between them. No changes were observed in 6MWT walking distance, with a small effect size.
population_specificity: Adult kidney transplant recipients of both genders.
effective_dosage: 35 Hz, twice a week for 12 weeks on alternate days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of PAH-targeted therapies on haemodynamic parameters and secondary outcomes like 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) in patients with group 3 pulmonary hypertension (PH).
results_summary: PAH-targeted therapies significantly improved mean pulmonary arterial pressure (mPAP), pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR), and 6MWD by 38.5 meters, but did not improve cardiac index (CI), right atrial pressure (RAP), quality of life (QoL), or BNP values.
population_specificity: Patients with group 3 pulmonary hypertension (PH) due to lung disease and/or hypoxia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current understanding of degenerative myelopathies, including assessment tools like the 30-m walking test, but did not specifically study walking as an intervention.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific findings about walking's effects, only mentioning it as one of several assessment tools for myelopathies.
population_specificity: Patients with degenerative myelopathies of the cervical and thoracic spine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of split-belt treadmill walking on step length symmetry in individuals poststroke during and after training.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that split-belt treadmill training with the shorter step length on the fast belt could improve step length symmetry in poststroke individuals, particularly with long-term training, though randomized controlled trials are needed to confirm efficacy.
population_specificity: Individuals poststroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of secondary cerebellopontine angle oligodendroglioma after cranial irradiation and describe its clinical presentation, including walking instability.
results_summary: The study found that the patient experienced walking instability as part of the clinical presentation of the tumor. The tumor was subtotally removed, and the patient recovered well post-surgery with adjuvant therapy.
population_specificity: A 25-year-old male with a history of grade II astrocytoma and postoperative radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a six-month brisk walking and balance program could alleviate motor symptoms and improve functional, gait, and balance performance in people with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The brisk walking group showed significant improvements in motor symptoms, gait speed, walking capacity, and dynamic balance compared to the control group, with sustained benefits at six months.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease (n=70, 64 completed).
effective_dosage: 10 supervised 90-minute sessions (weeks 1-6: once/week, weeks 7-26: once/month) plus 2-3 self-practice sessions weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether eccentric exercise could strengthen lower extremity muscles and improve gait autonomy in post-stroke hemiparetic patients.
results_summary: The study found significant increases in muscle strength (1RM) and walking speed (6MWT) in the intervention group, though no significant difference was observed in the 10-meter test between groups. Eccentric training was concluded to be beneficial for gait performance in post-stroke patients.
population_specificity: Thirty-seven hemiparetic adults post-stroke.
effective_dosage: Three sets of five repetitions of eccentric contraction of the paretic limb after determining the maximum repetition (1RM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and compare the properties, advantages, and disadvantages of commercial exoskeletons for lower limb impairments, focusing on feasibility, innovation, and design challenges.
results_summary: The study found significant differences among exoskeletons in terms of speed, torque, weight, autonomy, and user interaction, highlighting the need for improved hardware and control strategies to enhance assist-as-needed schemes.
population_specificity: Individuals affected by lower limb impairments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if moderate physical activity (including walking) improves quality of life, wellness, and cognitive functioning in older adults.
results_summary: The study measured quality of life, walking speed, and postural sway, suggesting potential benefits of moderate physical activity, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Over-65 males and females without medical contraindications to physical activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) classification using the six-minute walk test (6MWT) distance in asymptomatic adults, comparing it with treadmill maximum oxygen uptake (V˙O2).
results_summary: The study found that the CRF classification by the 6MWT distance is valid when compared with V˙O2, suggesting it can effectively assess cardiorespiratory fitness in asymptomatic adults.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of supervised progressive resistance training, supervised Nordic Walking, and unsupervised home-based exercise on muscle and functional performance in individuals with hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Nordic Walking showed no significant improvements in muscle mass, strength, or power compared to resistance training, but it was associated with some functional performance improvements. Resistance training was more effective for muscle mass but less so for strength, power, and functional performance.
population_specificity: 42 patients with hip osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a supervised walking-based rehabilitation program for individuals with lasting COVID-19 symptoms.
results_summary: The 6-week walking rehabilitation program significantly improved exercise capacity, respiratory symptoms, fatigue, and cognition, with no serious adverse events or dropouts due to symptom worsening. Participants showed notable improvements in walking tests (112 m on Incremental Shuttle Walking Test and 544 seconds on Endurance Shuttle Walking Test).
population_specificity: 30 individuals with lasting COVID-19 symptoms (mean age 58, SD 16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the definition of neuromuscular taping (NMT) and its potential effects on diabetic foot, focusing on improving walking function and related outcomes.
results_summary: NMT was found to improve walking function, leg position, pain response, muscle strength, motor function, range of movement, joint stability, and wound healing in diabetic foot patients. It also reduced edema and stiffness.
population_specificity: Diabetic foot patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of lateral stair walking training on muscle strength, balance, ADLs, and gait ability in patients with chronic stroke.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in hip muscle strength, gait parameters, balance, and ADLs compared to the control group, with notable differences in ankle plantar strength, PASS, BI, TUG, and gait velocity.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic stroke.
effective_dosage: 15 minutes of lateral stair walking exercise plus 15 minutes of traditional physiotherapy, once a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether performance-based balance tests could predict future falls in established unilateral transtibial prosthesis users.
results_summary: The study found that no combination of performance-based balance tests alone predicted future falls, but a model combining recalled falls, Timed Up-and-Go, and Four-Square Step Test times did predict falls over six months. Narrowing Beam Walking Test scores were not predictive.
population_specificity: Established, unilateral transtibial prosthesis users (n=45).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the terminology, exercise testing protocols, and modalities used to measure maximal walking distance in patients with intermittent claudication and assess the implementation and reporting quality of these protocols.
results_summary: The study found significant heterogeneity in terminology, testing protocols, and endpoints for measuring maximal walking distance, with no single trial fully meeting implementation and reporting criteria. Poor reporting and implementation further complicate between-study comparisons.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a bi-axial ankle muscle training program with visual feedback could improve ankle strength, functional performance, and walking speed in stroke patients with gait impairments.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in ankle muscle strength, walking speed, and muscle efficiency in the experimental group compared to the control group, with notable within-group improvements in ankle proprioception and walking speed.
population_specificity: Twenty-five stroke patients with walking difficulties (e.g., foot drop) or ankle muscle weakness receiving inpatient rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: 40 minutes per day, 5 times per week.
